repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR adds support for alternative definition of optional [1] type.

Partially implements #6254

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.Optional

comment_data.body:
Unless there's a good reason for this that I'm missing, I'd declare this with all the other builtin types in Cython/Compiler/Builtins.py.

It isn't obvious to me where the `__bool__` overload is actually used?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body: Doesn't this allow code like `cdef None x` or `x: None = 25` ? It seems to me that `Optional[]` or `Union[]` might just be special enough to specifically look for `None` in their type arguments rather than treating `None` as a type generally. `None` really isn't a type, it's a value that is allowed by the type system for practical syntax purposes (because writing `NoneType` would be awkward).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
`is_optional()` feels unclear to me as a name. It doesn't strictly refer to `typing.Optional`, just to something that is "optional" in whatever way.

Isn't a name like `allows_none` more concrete for the purpose?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4707,6 +4707,13 @@ class PythonTypeConstructorMixin:
     """Used to help Cython interpret indexed types from the typing module (or similar)
     """
     modifier_name = None
+    contains_none = False
+
+    def is_optional(self):

comment_data.body:
> Doesn't this allow code like `cdef None x` or `x: None = 25` ?

`cdef None` is not allowed even in this PR - I can add test for that if needed:
```
(cython311) root@c113a6388b51:~/dev/cython/test# cat aa.pyx
cdef None x
(cython311) root@c113a6388b51:~/dev/cython/test# cython -3 aa.pyx

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef None x
     ^
------------------------------------------------------------

aa.pyx:1:5: 'None' is not a type identifier
```
And `x: None` is already allowed in master (I suspect it fallbacks to `object`)

> It seems to me that Optional[] or Union[] might just be special enough to specifically look for None in their type arguments rather than treating None as a type generally. 

We need to have `None` type here to distinguish two cases:
1. `None` value in type definition (e.g. `Union[None, ExtentionType]`) and
2.  unknown type (e.g. `Union[ExtentionType, NonExistingType]`) - in this case we are having `None` value in `specialize_here()` function:

https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6333/files#diff-7f63ffd84e67d3d113d7ad10fa110111c779a8ca5edd7e12dc51097b36405eabR4773-R4785

> None really isn't a type

I don't fully agree. There is `None` type but is not part of public CAPI [1] of python (and this PR it uses just internal representation of this type - not using python CAPI):
```
>>> type(None)
<class 'NoneType'>
```

In general, I am using `None` type only to distinguish `None` in type from unknown type. (Moreover it makes sense to me to use type for `None`) If there is better/other solution I am fine to change the approach.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/none.html
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
> Isn't a name like allows_none more concrete for the purpose?

I am not good in naming things so I am totally fine on whatever has consensus among Core devs.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4707,6 +4707,13 @@ class PythonTypeConstructorMixin:
     """Used to help Cython interpret indexed types from the typing module (or similar)
     """
     modifier_name = None
+    contains_none = False
+
+    def is_optional(self):

comment_data.body:
> Unless there's a good reason for this that I'm missing, I'd declare this with all the other builtin types in Cython/Compiler/Builtins.py.

No reason except that I am still newbie in Cython codebase. I will move it.

> It isn't obvious to me where the `__bool__` overload is actually used?

In cython code there are parts where  you have line `if typevar:` (at least in code analysing binary operators or assignment) where in master `typevar` contains `None` but in this PR it is `PyNoneType`. `__bool__` ensures the `if` statements will be evaluated in the same way than before. If you want concrete example just comment out `__bool__` method and run tests - you will get test failures.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body:
> In cython code there are parts where you have line `if typevar:`

E.g. this line code:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/7e2cd6ad57c9eeb1fc6bf5d2bea469888a3f9b61/Cython/Compiler/ExprNodes.py#L12142
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body:
> `if type1 and ...`

Typically that'd be testing that `type1 is not None` which would mean it hasn't yet been analysed. That's different from "`type1` has been analysed and is known to be none_type".

I'll have a proper look later this week and try to understand where that's making a difference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4773,6 +4783,14 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         # Replace this type with the actual 'template' argument.
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
+class PyNoneType(BuiltinObjectType):

comment_data.body:
If we find `None` in code, we don't replace it with `None` as value, but with a `NoneNode`. That makes it easy to distinguish from the value `None` (as in "no node").

As you correctly wrote, the Python type is called `NoneType`, not `None`. The fact that Python uses `None` in the type system instead is simply that for users, typing `NoneType` is very unusual. Many programmers probably have never seen it but know `None` only as a constant value. Thus, `None` is ubiquitous and easy to read and understand as part of a type annotation â€“ it allows `None` as a value, thus making the typed value optional.

However, that doesn't mean that `None` *is* a type, or that we have to represent it as a type in Cython. Just check the type declaration node for `node.is_none` to see if we found `None` in the source code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
> However, that doesn't mean that `None` _is_ a type, or that we have to represent it as a type in Cython. Just check the type declaration node for `node.is_none` to see if we found `None` in the source code.

The core of this PR is following part:

```python
    def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
        if py_none_type in template_values:
            self.contains_none = True
```
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6333/files#diff-7f63ffd84e67d3d113d7ad10fa110111c779a8ca5edd7e12dc51097b36405eabR4782-R4784

Here, we are detecting whether annotation contains `None` (E.g. `Union[XYZ, None]`). I double checked it and without introducing `NoneType`, this code gets literal `None` value for both cases:

* `Union[int, None]`
* `Union[int, DummyType]`

Hence, without further changes I **cannot** distinguish following cases:
1. non-recognized type - in this case we should evaluate annotation as `object`
2. `None` value - in this case the type is candidate for evaluation of optional type - e.g. `Union[]`

> [!NOTE] 
> To replicate it, just use master and put debug print/breakpoint in following line:
> https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5805f4c0078e24438edb931a9846f83674c22059/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L4775
> Both cases
> ```python
> import typing
> 
> def main(a: typing.Optional[Bar]):
>     pass
> ```
> and
> ```python
> import typing
> 
> def main(a: typing.Optional[None]):
>     pass
> ```
> contains value `[None]` in variable `template_values`.

Hence, when I want to avoid introducing `NoneType` we need to introduce major structural changes how annotation is evaluated at least in following function (which feeds `specilize_here()`:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5805f4c0078e24438edb931a9846f83674c22059/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L1254
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

comment_data.body:
> we need to introduce major structural changes how annotation is evaluated at least in following function

Or implement the PR in totally different way, but in that case I have no idea how...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,9 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
             error(self.pos, "Cannot assign None to %s" % dst_type)
         return super().coerce_to(dst_type, env)
 
+    def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        return py_none_type
+

commit.message: Use is_optional() only if type is PythonTypeConstructorMixin
Handle case when ttype is None
